Expectation1: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation1: A minor UI glitch occasionally shows up but has an easy workaround
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: They are expected at routine meetings that occur frequently
Story: I stared at the bug report blinking on my screen, the QA’s note clear: “UI glitch appears intermittently—users can refresh to fix, but it’s annoying.” As a software developer, I knew I should jump in, trace the bug, and patch it before it became a bigger issue. My team expected quick turnarounds, and I prided myself on being reliable. But as I glanced at the clock, my heart sank. I had a routine advocacy meeting in fifteen minutes, and punctuality was non-negotiable. The legal team counted on me to be present, to represent our clients and keep cases moving. I felt the pressure mounting—if I stayed to fix the bug, I’d be late and let down my colleagues in advocacy. If I left now, the bug would linger, and my developer team would be frustrated. My mind raced, torn between two worlds, each demanding my full attention, each unwilling to wait. I hovered over my keyboard, paralyzed, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, unsure which expectation to let down.
